comments: After a(0) = 2 and a(1) = 3, this can never be prime, since a(n) = (a(n-1)+1) * (a(n-1)-1). Yet each term is relatively prime to its successor. The initial value a(0) is arbitrary, however these properties hold for any integer a(0) > 1. - _Jonathan Vos Post_, Jun 06 2008
references: R. K. Guy, How to factor a number, Proc. 5th Manitoba Conf. Numerical Math., Congress. Num. 16 (1975), 49-89.
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: A. V. Aho and N. J. A. Sloane, Some doubly exponential sequences, Fib. Quart., 11 (1973), 429-437.
Index entries for sequences of form a(n+1)=a(n)^2 + ...
mathematica: a=2; lst={a}; Do[b=a^2-1; AppendTo[lst,b]; a=b, {n,10}]; lst (* _Vladimir Joseph Stephan Orlovsky_, Dec 28 2010 *)NestList[#^2-1&,2,10] (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Nov 06 2011 *)
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_
